subject: Japanese Adjusted Trade Balance Total Yen Oct -302.7B vs. Exp. -483.0B (Prev. -240.0B)
EU Chief Negotiator Barnier has reportedly floated the idea of extending Brexit transition period by 2 years to end of 2022
Fairfax Media (FXJ AT) says shareholders overwhelmingly support proposed merger with Nine Entertainment (NEC AT) and expects implementation on December 7th
PRE-MARKET JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS:  SoftBank (9984 JT) Vision Fund is to invest USD 300mln in Automation Anywhere
content:
JAPAN

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. Saudi-backed Vision Fund is to invest USD 300mln in Automation Anywhere. (Newswires)

Takeda (6502 JT)
- Co. is to conduct a EUR 7.5bln bond issuance to help fund its purchase of Shire (SHP LN). (Newswires)

Other News
- Japanese PM Abe said he will order a 2nd extra budget after his return to Japan. (Newswires)
- Japan’s GPIF President Takahashi said on Friday that the fund is now able to hedge against fluctuation in the value of various currencies but did not disclose whether they had begun to do so. (Newswires)



SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. showcased its Santa Fe SUV with fingerprint access in China on Friday. (Yonhap)
- Co. and Kia Motors (000270 KS) are to invest a USD 250mln more in ride-hailing service Grab. (Newswires)

Other News
- US is said to seek high-level talks with South Korea by early next month. (Newswires)

subject: ERG sources are said to be confident of reaching the 48 letters required on Monday to trigger a no-confidence vote against UK PM May, according to Twitter reports
US is said to seek high-level talks with North Korea by early next month
US is said to seek high-level talks with North Korea by early next month
China's recent trade offer to the US is said to include additional purchases of US natgas and improved intellectual property protection
42 Tory MPs have given assurances in letters to not support PM May which is still 6 below the 48 needed for a no-confidence vote
Alumina (AWC AT) CFO Thiris is to retire effective December 31st and Co. has named Financial Controller Kraeva as interim CFO
UK Labour Party leader Corbyn says Labour Party cannot support PM May's Brexit deal
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: CBA Chairman and CEO are expected to face banking royal commission today
content:
Blue Sky Alternative Investments (BLA AT)
- Co. is expected to face class action litigation very soon related to investors’ losses. (AFR)

CBA (CBA AT)
- Co. Chairman Livingstone and CEO Comyn are expected to face the banking royal commission today. (AFR)

Computershare (CPU AT)
- Co. completed sale of 50% stake Karvy Computershare to General Atlantic. (Newswires)

Fonterra (FSF AT)
- Co. is said to be exploring a potential sale of South American operations which could be valued at NZD 1.0bln in addition to its ice cream brand. (Newswires)

Myer Holdings (MYR AT)
- Co. confirmed Q1 total sales fell 4.8% Y/Y, although its Q1 net loss improved from the prior year. (Newswires)

New Hope Corporation (NHC AT)
- Co. says it has a potential liability of AUD 130mln related to Colton Project. (Newswires)

Other News
- Australian PM Morrison was reportedly to have first meeting with Chinese President Xi and make efforts to ease recent tensions. (SCMP)

subject: Former UK Brexit Secretary Raab says PM May's plan is fatally flawed but can be saved and that EU is bullying UK, while he adds that he still supports PM May
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Japanese Trade Balance, Exports and Imports, Thailand GDP and BoJ Governor Kuroda Speech
Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson says UK should massively speed up preparations to exit the EU on WTO terms
ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

APEC summit ended without an agreement on a joint communique for the first time in its history after China refused to sign amid US-China tensions, while there had been comments from Chinese President Xi Jinping that countries which embraced protectionism were "doomed to failure" and US Vice President Pence later commented that he was prepared to "more than double" the tariffs imposed on Chinese goods. (BBC/AFR)

New Zealand Services PMI (Oct) 55.4 (Prev. 53.9). (Newswires)
New Zealand PPI - Outputs (Q3) Q/Q 1.5% (Prev. 0.9%)
New Zealand PPI - Inputs (Q3) Q/Q 1.4% (Prev. 1.0%)
 

UK

UK PM May stated over the weekend that there has not yet been enough number of letters required to trigger a no-confidence vote, while she added that that lawmakers should think about the need to deliver on Brexit and that the government would come back with proposals for the next step if Parliament votes against the deal. (Newswires)

Stephen Barclay was announced as the new Brexit Secretary, while The Sun’s Political Editor said the Brexit Sec role is being stripped down to just cover the domestic delivery of Brexit and that PM May will have sole charge of the final negotiations. There were also comments from UK Brexit Secretary Barclay said we must continue to build on momentum to finalise Brexit agreement. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney said there are no plans to start preparation of infrastructure for a potential hard border and that if Brexit looks inevitable, we need discussion on how to avoid a hard border. (Newswires)

FT Correspondent tweeted sources said they are looking at changing text of the withdrawal treaty to amend backstop while EU said text is done and dusted. (Twitter)


EU

S&P affirmed Switzerland at AAA; Outlook stable and affirmed Netherlands at AAA/A-1+; Outlook stable. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM DI Maio said he is in agreement with ECB President Draghi that the nation must lower its debt. (Newswires)

EU Commission is said to take first steps in disciplining Italy on November 21st over its budget proposal. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Baker Hughes Rig Count (16/Nov): Oil up 2 rigs at 888, gas down 1 rig at 194, total rigs up 1 at 1082. (Newswires)

OPEC delegates stated that a 1.0mln-1.4mln bpd cut is currently being discussed. (Platts)

Saudi Arabia reportedly wants oil prices around USD 80/bbl and also want to chart energy policy independent of US goals. (WSJ)

US forecasts a cut to Iranian crude sales by April of at least 40% to 900k BPD vs pre-sanctions levels, according to people familiar with the sanctions waivers. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said China wants to make a deal on trade but that it is not acceptable as it is now, while he added that US may not have to impose further tariffs. Trump also commented that hopefully US can make a deal with China but there must be reciprocal trade and that China list of tariff proposals is nearly complete although 4 or 5 things have been left off. (Newswires)

White House officials said that US President Trump was simply expressing optimism about current negotiations with China when he mentioned a halt in tariffs and added we shouldn't believe a deal is imminent. (CNBC/Twitter)

Fed Vice Chair Clarida (voter) noted there is some volatility around stock markets at the moment but no clear signal, while he added that he doesn't agree hikes are going too fast or too far and said that hikes have been gradual. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (non-voter, dove) does not believe that a December rate hike is prudent and said there is rising uncertainty about the outlook. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (non-voter, dove) said US economy is doing well and expects 3.25% GDP growth this year and 3.5% next year, while he added that wages have increased but not as much as would have expected.  Furthermore, Evans added he sees the current rate a little bit below neutral, getting to neutral is the "first order job" for the Fed. (Newswires)

US Industrial Production (Oct) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.2%). (Newswires)
US Manufacturing Output (Oct) M/M 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%, Rev. 0.3%)
US Capacity Utilization SA (Oct) 78.4% vs. Exp. 78.2% (Prev. 78.1%, Rev. 78.5%)

GEOPOLITICAL

CIA has reportedly concluded that the killing of journalist Khashoggi was ordered by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

Pacific Gas & Electric (PGE) surged back today, after its recent sharp selloff, due to California utility regulators saying it was unlikely the co. would become bankrupt; this also led to gains in local competitor Edison International (EIX). EOG Resources (EOG) was a top mover after an upgrade at Credit Suisse.  T-Mobile (TMUS) traded higher on the back of reports it could close its acquisition of Sprint (S) earlier than expected. NVIDIA (NVDA) nosedived following it reporting revenue beneath estimates, spreading wider pessimism across semiconductor stocks such as Advanced Micron Devices (AMD) and Micron Technology (MU). Nordstrom (JWN) dipped after missing EPS and revenue estimates. Michael Kors (KORS) was also a bottom mover on the back of a downgrade at Oppenheimer. SPX +0.2% at 2736, NDX -0.3% at 6867, DJI +0.5% at 25413.

Although Treasury yields were lower by between 4-5.5bps across the curve, major curve spreads saw some modest steepening, with the exception of the 2s5s part of the curve. Continued Brexit newsflow helped support have FI in European trade as Cabinet members announced their resignations. The complex stabilised after the US cash equity opened, and the T-Note future was traversing sideways , dipping only on Trump supposedly positive on trade talks with China; however, after officials walked-back from Trump’s comments, there was some slight selling, though the T-Note remained near session highs. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 11 ticks higher at 119-05.
